Patra Conceptualization Writing - review & editing * Department of Chemistry, Utkal University, Bhubaneswar 751004, India Department of Chemistry Utkal University Bhubaneswar 751004 India Department of chemistry, Utkal University, Bhubaneswar 751004, India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Alum doped nanopolyaniline, synthesized by using non-toxic potash alum as dopant was used as efficient catalyst for acylation of alcohols and amines under solvent-free condition. We report acylation of alcohols and amines employing acetic acid as an acylating agent in solvent free condition by using alum doped nanopolyaniline (NDPANI) as a catalyst. This environmentally benign method does not use corrosive acid anhydrides and acid chlorides for acylation and does not produce waste product. Also, a non-toxic potash alum was used for doping of polyaniline rather than corrosive acids. The reaction conditions represent an advance over established method not only in omitting the need for expensive catalysts or solvents but also in shortening the reaction time significantly. The advantages of this catalyst are non-hazardous, cheap, reusable, easy to prepare and handling. Keywords Polyaniline Heterogeneous catalyst Potash alum Solvent free Acylation 1 Introduction One of the efficient and easy way of protecting hydroxyl and amino group is acylation and useful in multistep organic transformations [1–11]. The ester moiety represents most functional groups in chemistry [12–16], playing a supreme role in biology [17–20] (Fig. 1 ) and serving as key intermediate as well as protecting group in organic transformations. On the other hand, the amide functionality is found in a wide variety of biological and synthetic structures such as proteins, pesticides, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals and polymer synthesis [21–24]. Generally, acetyl chloride and acetic anhydride are used as acylating agent in presence of catalytic amount of acid or base [25]. However, the corrosive and lacrimatory nature of both the reagents restricts its use. Acetic acid is reported as an alternative regent for the acylation of alcohol. The use of acetic acid in lieu of acetic anhydride or acetyl chloride is economically and environmentally preferable as it obeys the atom economy as well as reduces the waste which is highly desirable in industrial applications. Lewis acid such as scandium trifluoromethanesulfonate [26], trimethylsilyl trifluoromethanesulfonate [27], zinc chloride [28], cobalt chloride [29] and a variety of catalysts such as p-tolenesulphonic acid [30], Cu(OTf)2 [31], Mg(NTf)2 [32], In(OTf)3 [33], Ce(OTf)3 [34], silver triflate [35], MgBr [36], Mg(ClO4)2 [37], HClO4-SiO2 [38], ZrCl4 [39], iodine [40], alumina [41] are reported as catalysts for acylation of alcohol (Fig. 2 a). Moreover, the drawbacks associated with the use of these catalysts are expensive, moisture sensitive and contribute towards waste production due to destroy of Lewis acid during work-up. To overcome these problems insoluble catalysts such as KFAl2O3 [42], molecular sieves [43], zirconia [44], zeolite LAY [45], HY [46] were developed. Most of these catalysts are still utilized in presence of acetic anhydride as acylating reagents, while triflates are soluble in the reaction medium and difficult to recover for reuse. On the other hand, polymer-based catalyst gaining popularity in organic synthesis because of easy separation and reusability [47]. One of the most important features of polymer supported catalyst is that it can be conveniently recovered and reused. Polyaniline received considerable attention in the recent decade due to its unique physical and chemical properties such as environmental stability, easy synthesis and inexpensive [48–52]. Polyaniline has been extensively studied as a novel material for potential application in battery [53], chemical sensor [54,55], adsorbents [56–58], catalysis [59–62]. Albeit few polyaniline based catalyst [63–65] has been reported for acylation of alcohol and amine, still there is a need to develop reusable, inexpensive and solvent free heterogeneous catalyst for acylation of alcohol following atom economy. In our endeavour to propel green chemistry and sustainable development, we explored the catalytic activity of the alum doped polyaniline (NDPANI), (Fig. 2b) a green catalyst, synthesized by using a nontoxic potash alum as dopant. In this work, we established a method which is free from hazardous acylating agents (acetic anhydride and acetyl chloride) for acylation of alcohol and amine by using acetic acid in presence of a green catalyst NDPANI under solvent free condition. (Fig. 2b) No waste is generated in this method and the work-up is simple. The catalyst is separated from the reaction mixture by simple filtration and the catalyst can be reusable for multiple times without significant loss of catalytic activity. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Ammonium Persulfate (APS) ((NH4)2S2O8) (Merck, India), Potassium Aluminium Sulfate (Potash Alum) (Merck, India), Tetrahydrofuran (THF) (Merck, India), Toluene (SRL India) were used as received. Substituted alcohols and amines (Merck, India), Hexane (SRL India), Chloroform (SRL, India) and Ethyl acetate (SRL, India) were used as received. 2.2 Synthesis of alum doped nanopolyaniline The Catalyst (NDPANI) was synthesized by following the procedure as described by Majhi et al. [57] In a typical procedure, 2 mmol (0.182 mL) of freshly distilled aniline was added to 5 mL of toluene in a flask and stirred it for 30 min, to mix well. To this a solution of 0.228 g. of APS in 10 mL of 1 M HCl was added slowly. The resulting solution was stirred for 24 h for complete polymerization. Nanopolyaniline was obtained and filtered followed by washing with de-ionised water. The precipitated cake was further treated with 0.1 M NH4OH solution and stirred to obtain the emeraldine base form of the nanopolyaniline powder (EBPANI). Then filtered and washed with distilled water, and the nanopolyaniline was then dried in vacuum for at least 24 h. Then, 100 mg of nanopolyaniline base in 15 mL of THF was taken and to this 25 mL of 0.1 M aqueous potassium aluminium sulphate (potash alum) solution was added and stirred for 24 h. The doped polyaniline was filtered and washed with 150 mL of water. The powder was dried in the vacuum at 50 °C for 24 h. The alum doped nanopolyaniline samples were characterized by FTIR, Scanning Electron microscopy (SEM), EDX and TEM. 2.3 General procedure for acylation of alcohols and amines In a typical reaction procedure, substituted alcohols (1.5 mmol) or amines (1.5 mmol) with acetic acid (3 mmol) were taken in to 50 mL round bottom flask and 0.037 g (0.3 mol %) of NDPANI catalyst added to the reaction mass. The reaction was maintained at 100 °C with constant stirring. The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC. After completion of the reaction, the catalyst was recovered from the reaction mixture by simple filtration and washed several times with ethyl acetate, then dried in the oven for reuse. To remove excess acetic acid, saturated solution of NaHCO3 was added to the reaction mixture. The product was extracted with chloroform and the organic layer was dried by using anhydrous Na2SO4 and evaporated under vacuum. In few cases the crude product was then subjected to a short silica bed with hexane and ethyl acetate (8:2) mixture to eluate the corresponding acetate/amide products in high purity. All the products were characterized by using 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra. 2.4 Characterization techniques FTIR spectrum was recorded in PerkinElmer Spectrophotometer in the range of 400 to 4000 cm−1. Scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) (Carl Zeiss) and Transmission electron microscope (TEM) (Carl Zeiss) were used for determination of the morphology and particles size of NDPANI respectively. Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) (Carl Zeiss) was used to calculate the elemental content of NDPANI. 1H and 13C NMR was recorded in JOEL (400 MHz) and Bruker, Avance III (400 MHz) spectrophotometer using CDCl3 as solvent. 3 Characterization of catalyst 3.1 Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) Fig. 3 shows the FTIR spectra of emeraldine base polyaniline (EBPANI) and alum doped nanopolyaniline (NDPANI). The characteristic bands of EBPANI are observed at 1587 cm−1 (C=C Stretching of quinoid), 1495 cm−1 (C=C Stretching of benzoid), 1295 cm−1 (C-N stretching vibration) and 1162 cm−1 (aromatic imine C=N stretching) and 818 cm−1 (C-H bending) [66,67]. It is observed that after doping with potash alum, the band at 1587 cm−1 (quinoid) and 1495 cm−1 (benzoid), of EBPANI show a red shift to 1576 cm−1 and 1463 cm−1 in the spectrum of NDPANI respectively. This clearly indicated the interaction of potash alum with EBPANI resulted in delocalization of π electrons. The band at 1295 cm−1 (C-N stretching vibration) and 1162 cm−1 (aromatic imine C=N stretching) present in EBPANI also shifted to the lower frequency at 1286 cm−1 and 1110 cm−1 in NDPANI respectively. There is an extensive increase in the intensity of the band at 1110 cm−1 in NDPANI compared to undoped EBPANI. This can be attributed to the increase in delocalization of charge (or conjugation) over polymer chain due to pseudo-protonation of imine nitrogen of EBPANI by aluminum ion (Al+3). These values are in good agreement with those reported previously for polyaniline doped with copper and iron [68]. The surface morphology was analyzed by FE-SEM. The FE-SEM image shown in Fig. 4 a clearly shows the porous structure of the NDPANI resulted due aggregation of the particles. It is well agreement with the previous report that polyaniline tends to aggregates during polymerization [69]. This is also supported by the Transmission Electron Microscopy image (TEM) which revealed the agglomerations of particles and particle size ranges from 10 nm to 90 nm. (Fig. 4b). The presence of elements such as C, N, O, Al and S in the sample was confirmed by recording of EDX spectrum of NDPANI (Fig. 1, supplementary data). The elemental mapping shows the uniform distribution of the elements C, N, O, Al and S present in the sample (Fig. 2, supplementary data), which futher indicate that aluminium present in the catalyst is uniformly distributed after doping with alum. The structure of alum doped nanopolyaniline is shown in the Fig. 2b. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy EDX mapping provided further evidence that Carbon, Nitrogen, Oxygen, Aluminum and Sulphur are present in the polymer sample. The aluminium is doped to the polymer backbone resulting a pseudo-protonation. The total charge is neutralized by three sulphate ions, which act as counter anion. 4 Results and discussion Initially, acylation of benzyl alcohol (1.5 mmol, 0.14 mL) was carried out using acetic acid (3 mmol, 0.18 mL) as acylating agent in absence catalyst and solvent. The acylation of benzyl alcohol is almost failed to proceed in absence of catalyst when treated at 100 °C for 24 h (entry 1, Table 1 ). In contrast both 0.1 and 0.2 mol % of catalyst exhibited considerable yield at 100 °C under same reaction condition (entry 2, 3 Table 1). However, the yield was excellent (94 %) with the shorten reaction time when 0.3 mol % of catalyst was used at same temperature without leaching of aluminium. (entry 4, Table 1). Loading with higher amount of catalyst (0.4 %) resulted in marginal changes in the yield. Further temperature screening shows that 100 °C is the optimum temperature for the reaction (entry 5–8, Table 1). In order to know the effect of solvent, the reaction was conducted in presence of different solvents such as acetonitrile and dichloromethane using 0.3 mol % of catalyst at 100 °C for 3 h. The results are summarized in the (entry 9 & 10) Table 1. The yield of the reactions in presence of acetonitrile and dichloromethane were 69 and 72 % respectively under above condition. The decrease in yield in case of acetonitrile may be attributed to the blocking of some active site of catalyst due to formation of complex between Al+3 and acetonitrile [70]. This result is similar to those reported for acylation of alcohol and amine by polyaniline supported FeCl3 [65]. However, the maximum yield is observed when the reaction is carried out in absence of any solvent. Furthermore, catalytic activity of EBPANI (Emeraldine base of nanopolyaniline) and potash alum, were checked at same reaction condition. It is worthy to note that the reaction was slow with maximum yields 67 % and 72 % for EBPANI and potash alum respectively within 12 h. Acylation in presence of mixture of both EBPANI and potash alum (without the process of doping) was examined under same reaction condition (entry 13, Table 1) showed 68 % yield which is lower in comparison to the reaction carried out in presence of 0.3 mol % of NDPANI. With this optimal reaction conditions identified, the scope of acylation is extended to various alcohols. Both electron withdrawing and electron donating substituents of benzyl alcohols afford the corresponding ester in good to excellent yields (86 %–95 %). (Table 2 , entry 1–6). It should be noted that in many cases the products can be directly isolated with excellent purity by simple removal of the catalyst via filtration and evaporation of the solvent. After successful acylation of alcohol, we turned our attention towards varieties of amine, phenol and cyclohexanol under solvent free condition. The results are summarized in Table 2. It is noteworthy to report that acylation of phenol is slower when compared to that of amine. (entry 10) Among the various amines studied, the acylation of secondary amine was found to be slower and required more time than that of primary aromatic amine and aniline. Aromatic amines that were substituted by electron withdrawing group (p-nitroaniline) reacted slowly than that possess electron donating group (p-bromoaniline). The plausible mechanism of acylation of alcohols and amines with acetic acid in presence of alum doped nanopolyaniline (NDPANI) catalyst under solvent free condition is shown in Fig. 5 . It is assumed that due to interaction of aluminium of NDPANI with oxygen of carbonyl group, the carbon atom of carbonyl group becomes more reactive towards nucleophilic attack of oxygen, nitrogen atom of alcohol and amines respectively. Finally, dehydration makes the ester and amide bond stable. To test the reusability of the catalyst, the catalyst was removed from reaction mixture by simple filtration. It was washed with ethyl acetate several times and dried, before reused as a catalyst. Reusability of the catalyst was checked by repeating five times the reaction of benzyl alcohol and acetic acid under optimal reaction condition resulting ester with almost same yield (89–93 %). Very little loss of catalytic activity was observed after five consecutive cycles (Fig. 6 ). Thus, the catalyst can be efficiently reused for at least five cycles without any significant loss in activity. The superiority of the present catalyst can be evaluated by comparing with few reported protocols listed in Table 3 . It demonstrates that the present protocol is indeed superior to other protocol. Most of the catalysts shown here are either costly or contain corrosive acid or take longer time with low yield. The present protocol is effective in acylation of benzyl alcohol and aniline in 3 h and 1 h respectively whereas acylation carried out in presence of other catalyst required more time with elevated temperature. 5 Conclusions A versatile method for acylation of alcohols and amines by virtue of NDPANI is developed under solvent free conditions. This method includes a lot of unique merits namely, non-hazardous, a cheap and easy-to-handle catalyst, operational simplicity and no need of absolute dry reaction condition. Catalyst can be easily removed from the reaction mixture by simple filtration and can be reuse multiple times without loss of its catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: We report acylation of alcohols and amines employing acetic acid as an acylating agent in solvent free condition by using alum doped nanopolyaniline (NDPANI) as a catalyst. This environmentally benign method does not use corrosive acid anhydrides and acid chlorides for acylation and does not produce waste product. Also, a non-toxic potash alum was used for doping of polyaniline rather than corrosive acids. The reaction conditions represent an advance over established method not only in omitting the need for expensive catalysts or solvents but also in shortening the reaction time significantly. The advantages of this catalyst are non-hazardous, cheap, reusable, easy to prepare and handling.
coredata.dc:title: An efficient, economical and eco-friendly acylation of alcohols and amines by alum doped nanopolyaniline under solvent free condition
